awd_titl_txt: Structural and areal challenges to models of language change
awd_abstract_narration:
While linguists are aware of how language shift (the process by which a community of speakers changes from one language to another) plays a role in the demise of a language, significant questions remain, including how social and cognitive constraints shape language structure and how cognitive, social, and historical factors interact to result in language shift.  A related issue is that what linguists do know comes primarily from Indo-European languages like English or Latin, which restricts the possible data set in two ways: by the linguistic structures these languages lack and by the smaller set of social situations where language shift has occurred. In order to augment the typology of shift situations and linguistic structure, this project will investigate language change through a unique set of field notes and recordings of two endangered languages of northeastern Uganda collected from 1967-1971, and from new fieldwork with the remaining speakers. Because the target languages in this study diverge typologically from much of the existing sample of structural changes as languages cease to be spoken, they offer a control against the possible hypothesis that observed structural similarities across shifting languages are attributable to historically contingent interference rather than a universal markedness hierarchy of particular grammatical structures. Broader impacts of the project include advancing the training of a post-doctoral scholar and creating learning opportunities for undergraduate linguistics students to participate in and contribute to cutting-edge research. The project will ensure the Nyangi and Soo communities also get copies of the materials in this collection, as well as providing access to the broader community of scientific researchers. Finally, the project will promote international collaboration between scholars at American and Ugandan institutions.

The outcomes of situations in which an ancestral language is replaced by a non-European language are poorly understood. In part, analyses of language shift in languages shifting to non-European languages have been hard to come by because such languages often lack documentation from before the time that they started to shift. This means that there is no reference point to compare current linguistic forms to: linguists have ending points for the types of change undergone by languages, but not starting points. This project addresses this problem by making data accessible from Nyangi (nyp) and Soo (teu), two languages that are now being replaced by African languages. The data to be digitized and archived in this project includes approximately 26 hours of audio recordings on cassette tapes and reel-to-reel tapes and approximately 3,000 pages of hand-written field notes. The resulting collection of digitized recordings will be translated into English and into the language of broader communication used by the Nyangi and Soo. A selection of its contents will be analyzed and richly annotated in consultation with the Soo and Nyangi communities. Analyses of the typological and areal motivations for the changes observed in Soo and Nyang'i in the 50 years since the recordings in this collection were made will be permanently archived in a secure and accessible location, shared and discussed at scholarly conferences, and published in linguistics journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project digitized and archived a precarious collection of data from two critically endangered languages spoken in northeastern Uganda. It made these materials accessible to interested people by providing detailed descriptions of each item from the archive, including word-for-word and colloquial translations of audio recordings as well as information about the time, place, and participants involved in each item.

The project made contributions to scientific understanding in multiple domains. It helped clarify how ideas spread through East Africa in the distant past by providing new sets of data that were used in historical linguistic research; work in this project is particularly suggestive of tighter historical links between populations of northeastern Uganda and in Tanzania than has previously been understood, as demonstrated in an accepted handbook chapter awaiting publication at the end of this project. The project enlarged scholarly understandings of what is possible when languages have nearly completely fallen out of use through research findings in fieldwork among Nyangi people in Uganda. The Nyangi initiated their own language revitalization program, and the number of conversational speakers has more than tripled in the space of just eight years. The project has also contributed to ongoing issues in language archiving such as the question of how primary source materials can be discovered, why they get lost, and what it takes for primary source materials that have lost their institutional homes to survive—these questions are particularly pressing as every new year brings images of physical archives burning to the ground and stories of digital structures proving to be durable than promised. A key finding of the project is that data preservation and archiving are social tasks that are embedded in social contexts; their success or failure is deeply rooted in the motivations and relationships of the people involved. Consciously thickening and supporting the human connections that give personal meaning to records of the past is one way to better ensure the continued trustworthiness of the empirical base of linguistics, anthropology, and other social sciences. These ideas were developed in a journal article and in a series of conference talks.

A digital archive of audio files, field notes, and images produced in Uganda between 1963 and 1973 by John M. Weatherby is the key product of this project. It can be found at http://hdl.handle.net/2196/032185e4-d02f-47ef-9c41-dbfd8c12f0b6 . The archive contains about 25 hours of audio files, about 4,000 pages of field notes, and about 1,500 photographs. These materials provide a record of cultural and linguistic practices from the 1960s and 1970s that are no longer in use (the Nyangi language, included in some audio recordings, almost completely fell out of use in the ensuing 40-50 years, ultimately remembered by only a single person).

One way that this project provided broader impacts was by offering training and mentorship to undergraduate students, graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher, each of whom were trained in new strategies for data management and in new kinds of software for organizing data and making it accessible. Time on the project prepared the undergraduate research assistant to begin a graduate degree at his first choice of program at the project’s conclusion, and it positioned the postdoc to accept a tenure track position in linguistics.

The project also had broader impacts for the Soo and Nyangi community whose linguistic and cultural heritage is documented in the collection archived in this project. The postdoc was able to provide hard copy and digital copy versions of the materials from the archive to the Soo and Nyangi communities during a field trip in August 2022; continued collaborations with these communities will make the materials more accessible for the communities so that they can use the materials in their ongoing self-organized language revitalization programs. The Soo and Nyangi have been objects of external study who have not received access to the benefits of the external study for nearly a century; this project initiated the process of returning extracted heritage to their control.
